post.author: Mike
post.title: American Airlines 40% Bonus on Purchased Miles
post.content:
With the recent announcement from American Airlines, you might be asking "Is it worth it to buy miles with the new AA bonus?", and the answer is fairly simple: it depends on how many you're buying. As a consumer, you should have either or both of the following goals: to reach a particular rewards level, and to get as many bonus miles as you can for the lowest possible cost.

 


The Numbers

If you're asking "Is it worth it to buy miles with the new AA bonus?", then here are the basic numbers for the program to help explain the cost and value.

American Airlines' bonus offer, available through the AAdvantage program, follow a basic tiered structure in terms of how many rewards miles are available. Notably, all miles much be purchased in a single transaction to be eligible for the rewards, so you will need to pay all at once if you want to maximize your returns. The basic levels are as follows:

  • 1000 Miles: No bonus miles, and the lowest level that can be purchased. A cost of $29.50 gives a per-mile cost of 2.95 cents.
  • 15,000 Miles: A bonus of 3750 miles, with a total cost of $412.50 and a per-mile cost of 2.42 cents.
  • 30,000 Miles: A bonus of 8250 miles, with a total cost of $825.00 and a per-mile cost of 2.15 cents.
  • 45,000 Miles: A bonus of 13,500 miles, with a total cost of $1237.50 and a per-mile cost of 2.11 cents.
  • 65,000 Miles: A bonus of 26,000 miles, with a total cost of $1787.50 and a per-mile cost of 1.96 cents.
  • 80,000 Miles: Also a bonus of 26,000 miles, with a total cost of $2200.00 and a per-mile cost of 2.07 cents. This is the highest level that can be purchased, and the maximum number of bonus miles that can be purchased in the AAdvantage program for a calendar year.

As you can see, there is an actual benefit to purchasing miles in bulk - at each bonus tier, they cost measurably less, but buying more than the minimum for each level offers decreased returns on the investment.

The almost half-cent difference between the lowest and the highest reward tiers doesn't sound like much at first, but it does add up to a lot of savings - if the rates were the same, the highest reward level (i.e. 65,000 miles) would have a total cost of around $2200 dollars, which is the same as the cost of the maximum number of miles.

Note, however, that these prices do not include taxes or the $40 transaction charge. Such fees will increase the per-mile cost somewhat, depending on where you live and what taxes are applicable.

Historical Comparison

This deal is not the greatest deal that American Airlines has ever offered. In fact, earlier this year they had a deal working out to less than 2 cents per mile after taxes, and it's quite possible that they'll have a better deal later in the year as well... or they might not. The airline industry changes dynamically, and leaving one deal behind in hopes of getting a better one is a bit of a risk.

However, if you're asking "Is it worth it to buy miles with the new AA bonus?", there's one other problem to take into consideration: American Airlines has a per-year limit on the number of bonus miles you can purchase. Namely, you can only buy 80,000 miles per calendar year, and hitting the highest possible reward level will just barely leave you the room to buy a second deal at the lowest rewards level in the future... assuming that American Airlines continues to offer rewards at 15,000 miles. They probably will, but that can't be guaranteed.

So, is it worth it to buy miles with the new AA bonus?

If you fly rather regularly... yes, it is worth it. This deal isn't absolutely fantastic, but it can still provide a good value for anyone planning on a long-distance trip. In the interest of full disclosure, I decided not to purchase these myself since I prefer to wait for deals that are a little better when I'm getting rewards miles in bulk.

The Fine Print

American Airlines has a breakdown of the limitations on their official purchasing portal. Be sure to read all of these restrictions very carefully if you're thinking about purchasing any number of bonus miles. Keep in mind that purchases like these generally can't be combined with many other offers and rewards, and are subject to other limitations that American Airlines has imposed.
